Award.AwardTitle: Conference: Reflections on the Impact of the Reconstruction Amendments: A Research Symposium on the Social and Economic Outcomes of the 13th, 14th, and 15th Amendments

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This is a research symposium and conference on the social and economic outcomes of the 13th, 14th, and 15th Amendments. It will be held at the National Archives building. These Amendments to the US Constitution were passed in the period 1865 - 1870. The title of this project reflects the general theme of the event and the projected activities for the conference. It has two major goals. The focused goal of this event is to bring together an interdisciplinary group of undergraduates, graduate students, and senior scholars in STEM disciplines to explore, in a research context, the long evolution of economic and race inequality in the US, despite these three Amendments, over the course of the century and a half after their passage into law. A second longer term goal is to continue to develop laddered research settings in higher education that combine the efforts of undergraduate students, graduate students, post-doctoral scholars, and faculty in a conscious effort to provide new research findings and expose undergraduates to rich research in the social sciences.

The 13th Amendment to the United States Constitution officially abolished and continues to prohibit slavery. The 14th Amendment to the United States Constitution declared that all persons born or naturalized in the United States are American citizens, including African Americans. The 15th Amendment to the United States Constitution prohibits each government in the United States from denying a citizen the right to vote based on that citizen's race, color, or previous condition of servitude. The value in a focused study these Amendments is that their full enactment did not become fully operational in the legal sense until the mid-1960s. The early promise of these amendments was reduced by state laws and federal court decisions over the course of the 19th century. Their promise was legally re-affirmed in the 1950s and 1960s, but the real social and economic implications took another half century to fully define.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Samuel DuBois Cook Center on Social Equity at Duke University, in conjunction with the Joint Center for Political and Economic Studies, hosted a conference in Washington, D.C., on March 14-17, 2017 entitled Reflections on the Impact of the Reconstruction Amendments: A Research Symposium on the Social and Economic Outcomes of the 13th, 14th, and 15th Amendments. The overarching goal of this conference, was to bring together an interdisciplinary group of undergraduate, graduate students and senior scholars in STEM disciplines to explore the long evolution of economic and racial inequality in the United States since the passage of these three amendments. Funding for the conference was provided by the National Science Foundation, Kellogg and Ford Foundations. The conference was devoted to characterizing the state of knowledge and identification of critical new directions for research in the social and behavioral sciences, and on economic inequality in the context of the impact of the Reconstruction Amendments. Conferees included interdisciplinary teams of undergraduate and graduate students, senior scholars from Duke University and other institutions from across the United States. The event was held at the National Archives Museum and the new National Museum of African American History and Culture, giving participants the opportunity to see historical documents related to the period.  Highlights included keynote addresses from Principal Investigator, William Darity, Professor of Public Policy, Economics, and African and African American Studies at Duke University on the State of Black America 150 Years after Emancipation; John W. Franklin gave remarks on historian John Hope Franklin’s legacy and the history of the African American Museum of History and Culture. A robust discussion of the documentary, 13th was led by the cinematographer of the film, Hans Charles. Panel discussions about the amendments were held, consisting of students, faculty and scholars. The conference also featured workshops with undergraduate and graduate students exploring questions related to conducting research related to social inequality topics in the academy.

A manualof findings of the conference was developed that will serve as a resource for students and faculty. Materials from the conference were also used as part of the curriculum for the undergraduate and graduate seminar, Global Inequality Research Initiative taught at Duke University.
